captions.text:
Bill Nye: So SpaceX is a response to the history
of space exploration. This is my point of

view. So one of the magical things about NASA,
the National Aeronautics and Space Administration

here in the U.S., is the administration has
stayed about the same for, 1958, what is that,

56 years. The reason is Congress had either
the ignorance or the genius to put a dozen

NASA centers in 13 different places around
the US. And when you try to close a NASA center

in Congress, people come unglued. You can't
close a NASA center. This is how people got

to the moon. When John Kennedy was shot, which
was an awful thing, any idea to cancel the

moon program was squashed. As soon as Kennedy
was shot we couldn't not, not go as the expression

goes. So humans went to the moon, the space
program existed, changed the world in a great
way, however, it made things expensive.

When you build rocket engines in Alabama and
you get the fuel from Utah and you test them

in Mississippi and you then send them to Florida
and control all that from Texas, with some

drop testing done in Cleveland and all sorts
of material science research done in California,

some flight tests done in the desert in Arizona,
when you do all that you just add cost. When

you go to SpaceX, the material, the stainless
steel and the aluminum come off the train

cars. It goes through the factory like this.
We make our tanks. We make our space frame

or airframe. We make our rocket engine bells.
We hook up all our plumbing. It goes back

this way. We do the wiring and it goes back
on the train car and goes to either Vandenberg

Air Force Base or Cape Canaveral because it's
all made in one place. But the way NASA was

established in 1958, it's not set up that
way and that was good and bad.

So it is to be hoped that SpaceX, Sierra Nevada
Space, Blue Origins, that these companies

will emerge and lower the cost, especially
of taking stuff to low earth orbit. Keep in

mind everybody, for all the free market libertarian
let's go laissez-faire people, SpaceX has

taken at least half a billion dollars, $500
million from NASA because NASA wants to develop

this capability. When you buy an Atlas V rocket
or a Delta IV rocket those are commercially

made gizmos, and so is going to be the Falcon
and Falcon Heavy. These are commercial rockets

and NASA has gone to great lengths to develop
that business. It's all good. It's all good.

I would go to space like that. I applied to
be an astronaut four times. I would love to

get a view of the earth from space. And right
now the price is $200,000, it starts to come

down into the 10th of that I could imagine
doing it. If you've never jumped out of a

plane with a parachute, that is cool. I don't
do it full-time but I get it. It's exciting

and you do see the world in a new way and
you're in the air. Everybody's dream is to

be able to fly. You're flying for a few moments.
I get it. I can see how people get hooked

on that. And I think space exploration would
be the same deal.

title: Bill Nye on the Remarkable Efficiency of SpaceX

comments.text:
Private companies have always and will always be better than government 
funded agencies.﻿
comments.author: Alex Hall

comments.text:
Bill Nye "The Science Guy of 25 years ago" says he would start to imagine 
going to space once it costs 1/10 of $200,000!!! What kind of Science guy 
is that for you? Cheap sumbtch! He'd rather go to a casino or something I 
guess :)﻿
comments.author: Josh Worley

comments.text:
It's good to hear him talk about the production and logistics behind the 
space industry.﻿
comments.author: Space Ventures Investors

comments.text:
It is typical for people to make sweeping generalizations about private vs 
public based on a single anecdotical evidence. NASA is help up as the 
inefficiency of the public sector. Conveniently forgetting that Boeing and 
Lockheed Martin are private companies and have been comparably bloated and 
inefficient at bring about a new usable rocket. Russian Space Agency have 
also managed to build rockets for way lower cost that NASA. That is why the 
Russian got most of the world's launches. They did all of this on budgets 
less than 1 tenth of the NASA budget. They are public. So clearly it isn't 
about public vs private but how each individual organization is run.

SpaceX does well for many of the same reasons as any startup company 
usually does better than established behemoths. Startups are usually full 
of dedicated people eager to make a difference and open to doing things in 
a new way. 

And one might wonder what sort of failure NASA really is as they are not so 
much developing rockets as they are managing money and providing expertise 
to various private contractors. The failure is just as much with these 
private contractors as it is with NASA. Ultimately I'd say the problem is 
NASA being hamstrung too much political meddling. The answer isn't to close 
down NASA or privatize it but to make it independent and not subject to the 
whims of politicians.﻿

Libertarian is not an economic belief, as he is implying. Libertarianism is

socialist societies. 
He just confused something I strongly agree with, Liberatarian socialism

comments.author: William Readling

comments.text:
I would prefer that SpaceX receive contracts to do R&D on launch systems, 
but that might be too close to the truth.   By "giving" money to SpaceX 
without specifying by contract what it is for, the bureaucrats create an 
"excuse" for SpaceX doing what government could not, and much more cheaply.
Do you see how well the excuse worked for Bill Nye the Statist Guy?  
"You're wrong, SpaceX did a good job launching cargo, but only because 
government gave it money", as opposed to, "You're right, SpaceX did much 
better R&D, more cheaply than government ever could".
Government does two things well.  It does a good job at taking people's 
wealth by coercion, and it is good at hurting people.  Everything 
government does better than the private sector is based on 
coercion(violence, or it's threat) in one way or another.
comments.author: William Readling

comments.text:
Look at the procurement contracts, there was some "giving away" there. For 
example, NASA paid SpaceX 40 million dollars for hosting a meeting. I am 
not saying it is bad that NASA supported SpaceX, but there were some big 
giveaways.
comments.author: David n

comments.text: Love you Bill :) xx﻿

comments.text: I used to watch bill nye the science guy in 6th grade ﻿
comments.author: stitch6260

comments.text:
Ehh, if a company cannot exist without subsides it should not exist. The 
dead weight loss from taxation and redistribution is a net negative on the 
economy.

However, musk has noted that they could survive without their govt support. 
I think the main problem is that the economy has no demand for exploration, 
until there is commercial potential it won't be visited, and no commercial 
potential exists past GEO.﻿
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
@1133806799998065499331. Just letting companies die because of some 
libertarian principle is insanely stupid, each case has to be carefully 
evaluated. There are plenty of examples of companies that has a huge net 
benefit to the economy, but because of a few bad year, or a rough upstart, 
they needed help. One example is Harley Davidson, they would not be here 
today if it were not for the government, clearly worth saving.
Another more modern example, Tesla, would have gone down the shitter in the 
recession had it not been for government money. Which is now paid back 
fully, with interest.
And there are thousands of examples like that.
2. I doubt Space X could survive without gov support, or at least they 
would never accomplish anything meaningful. However more to the point, if 
it were not for government, there would not have been any moon landing or 
any of the space technology needed to even *think* about starting a private 
company.
A private company has to earn money every step of the way, the problem is 
that *reality* if full of investments that require many steps before any 
profit can bee seen.

Take for instance the LHC in Cern, maybe the most important and certainly 
most expensive science project in the history of mankind. And it would 
never have happened with private money, if you believe that you live inside 
a fairy tale mate:)
Almost all the research that is done by private companies is the kind of 
research where there is a clear goal, a clear path and a clear deadline, 
and a very clear profit motive. But that has never been how important 
science has been done. Almost all science that has ended up in real 
breakthroughs for humans have been the kind of science were we just build 
something, and start it up, and wait to see what happens.
*Then*, after all the important work is done, private companies swoop inn 
to reap the harvest and the market expands on it and make it cheap and 
available for the consumer. Which is a good thing, that's what markets are 
good at.
comments.author: Salty Admiral

comments.text:
Their original contract was cost plus. And your predictive abilities are 
sorely lacking, there is no example of a profitable venture not occurring 
without govt.
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
+Jon Jo Yes, your "cash prize" idea is actually how the NASA-SpaceX 
contract is modeled.

My point is, private industry would never be the first to take the plunge. 
Humanity would always be earth-bound if we relied solely on profit driven 
motives.
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
+David n Indeed, my point was that the reason "costs are going down" isn't 
because SpaceX is inventing new technologies. They are making their 
facilities more efficient by using innovation in other industries. For 
instance, they are using newer fabrication techniques from the airline 
industry, improved computing technology to do complex tasks (landing the 
first stage), and in general approaching this as an opportunity to cut 
cost. A smarter idea would NOT have been for NASA to use their subsidies 
models as they have done for half of a century, but to instead set cash 
prizes for people able to create the product they wanted. THAT would have 
been a more efficient use of resources, if instead private industry were 
the ONLY entity involved than space would be cheaper anyway as that is 
necessary in order to fly.

You repeatedly say that the costs are worth it, but I have found no 
evidence supporting that. Every bit of technology subsidized by NASA could 
have been done more efficiently in the private market (and would have been 
when it was demanded). This is the inherent problem with NASA, they focus 
on pointless boondoggles and being "first" rather than doing what makes 
sense which is to promote economic activity (by not existing).
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
+Jon Jo You know what I meant. 1890 would be more accurate.
You are wrong. *COSTS ARE GOING DOWN*, granted it took a private company, 
but let's not forget it was a private company with a blank check from NASA,
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
The Automobile didn't exist in 1870. But my point is that costs go down due 
to investment in economic areas (for instance, much of the improvement in 
computing in space technology came about through private industry and not 
the space program) and they do so much faster as the funding comes from a 
much larger source. IF costs AREN'T going down- that is because the 
industry makes no sense and should be allowed to shrink.
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text: +Jon Jo And how many people could afford cars in 1870?
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
I have found no evidence of this. Everything I have read indicates the 
costs to lift things into orbit are too high to justify any exploration.
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
+Jon Jo No, there *is* profit in space exploration. It's just that the 
market players don't want to invest the upfront cost.
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
This has nothing to do with finance. I am referring strictly to economics 
and you should know that military contractors and aerospace companies are 
heavily invested in by private investors.

There can also never be profit in an uneconomic activity unless the market 
allows it, currently the only areas with profit are in communication 
satellites.
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
+Jon Jo Your point - If a bunch of old white men running hedge funds don't 
like your idea - it obviously is a waste of time.

The fact is Space is *EXPENSIVE.* And old white men running hedge funds 
don't want to pay for it because they'll be dead before profit ever happens.
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
But you are being "silly" if you fail to understand that something not 
happening can be a good thing. If the economy doesn't demand something than 
it is a waste of money, that is simply a fact. The benefits of government 
don't extend to this area; the benefits are in the areas of stability and 
the area of contract law and property ownership. This is well outside of 
the benefits of government.

It doesn't matter that something isn't funded by government; if it makes 
economic sense it will be done- subsidies ALWAYS result in externalities 
which make the economy less efficient. 

Just as subsidizing agriculture increases obesity, subsidizing uneconomic 
R&D has a negative effect on the economy- it may not be large but it exists.
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
+Jon Jo You miss the point. LEO research - subsidized. HEO Russian missions 
- Subsidized. Recent explosion in commercial satellites - thank you 
subsidies.

You call manned space flight a "photo-op," I call it the future. Do you 
also believe the wright brothers were building a photo-op too? 
Interestingly, many of the biggest leaps in aviation history were privately 
funded ... oh wait ... publicly funded!

Believe it or not, the government is not an evil instrument that ruins 
everything it touches. I am all for "free-markets," but I'm not silly 
enough to think market capitalism is infallible.
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
+David n Not exactly "a few" there would still be incentive for the GEO 
syncs, LEO's for research, HEO for Russia and various other odd latitudes, 
etc. There likely wouldn't be manned expeditions- but those are expensive 
photo ops rather than necessary activities. Space is generally not a 
logical target, aside from comm satellites, TV, Radio, etc. there is no 
real reason to go there right now.

And BTW, if the economy ran in a  more efficient way factories would likely 
have more mechanization. And you miss the point of economic activity, as a 
market entity YouTube IS operating under the auspice of market activity. 
For something to work in an uneconomic way it has to generate dead-weight 
loss (True Monopoly, Monopsony, Government spending financed by taxation).
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
+Jon Jo But relying on market forces would mean only a few satellite 
launches. There would be no manned private space flight.

You studied economics. Why is this? Well it could be the huge upfront sunk 
costs and the high risk and low return threshold. Space is hard. Sometimes 
the infallible market needs a boost.

By the way, according to your "generating economic activity argument," we 
should all be working 17 hour days in steel mills, not commenting on 
YouTube. Gosh, how much economic activity has YouTube removed?
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
I never said that "investing in space is useless". I merely made the 
factual point that spending money on space travel (it isn't true 
investment) is guaranteed to result in less economic activity than would be 
the case if such were not done. This doesn't mean space travel is useless 
or that all space travel would go away, only that space travel which is 
created by non market forces and entities harms the economy.
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
+Jon Jo So your point is investing in space is useless? That's a very 
shortsighted view.
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
Private investment wouldn't pay for it, unless there was money to be made. 
This is the market's way of distributing money to where it will best be 
used. The time gap isn't the problem so much (pharmaceuticals have decades 
long gaps until they make money off of a drug) the problem is that there is 
NOTHING to make money off of. It is also true that the loss of individual 
businesses would be harmful to a certain segment of the economy but on NET 
the resulting removal of dead-weight loss and the return of that tax money 
is beneficial to the economy as a whole.

An example would be the massive drops in oil prices. By lowering the Price 
of Crude, certain segments of the economy suffer, but by shifting the 
aggregate supply curve to the left, the economy as a whole benefits.
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
+Jon Jo But here is my question. Why would private investors pay for 
sending astronauts to the space station? Why would private investors pay 
for a trip to Mars if they know they can't make a profit until extremely 
far into the future?

While subsidies are harmful, you need at least some government funding to 
cover the sunk cost of manned space exploration. And SpaceX is the closest 
to a truly private company you will find. If the government stopped all 
their payments to SpaceX, they would still be competitive.

And finally, why should the US stop subsidizing ULA, OSC, or SpaceX? 
Stopping them would only see them lose out to other countries (except for 
SpaceX, who could still be competitive). So much for "at least we're not 
destroying our economy!"
comments.author: David n

comments.text:
Indeed, and this reduces the efficiency and growth of the world economy. 
The dead-weight loss may be small but it still harms the health of the 
economy. Perhaps it is better that OTHER nations harm their economy while 
the one you live in does not.
comments.author: Jon Jo

comments.text:
Its all gud. Its aaall gud.







Ayy lmao﻿
comments.author: Dave

comments.text:
NASA and DARPA emerged out of the Cold War, and created multiple facilities 
and tied them together in case of an attack.  This way a) all of your eggs 
are not in your basket, b) machines were able to talk from MIT to Stanford 
with redundancy through UUnet et al e) missile silos burried underground in 
sparsely populated location d) Had to do with the visions of Eisenhower, 
JFK, and LBJ (can include Nixon on the Space Shuttle) e) more (this is what 
I can think of at the top of my head).  ﻿

comments.text:
SpaceX makes things cheaper because they make their employees work 70 hours 
a week for lower than average wage with no overtime pay. That cuts your

comments.author: Steve T

comments.text:
70 hours a week isn't common anymore. It has happened at times (with 
proper, compliant overtime pay) when a core is delayed for whatever reason 
and production needs to step up. You don't have to work 70 hours a week, 
average is around 55 hours. If you work below expectations, they will fire 
you, but if you can perform your required duties then they don't care how 
long you work. All they want is for you to perform their (very difficult) 
job requirements, which are laid out when you start.

If you work there, you should know what you are getting in to, but it's a 
startup culture where they need the best only, and so their job 
expectations are what only the best can accomplish.

comments.author: Daniel Brown

comments.text:
It can be said that this system basically killed the crew of Challenger 
51L. Morton Thiokol should have never gotten the Space Shuttle SRB 
contract. Aerojet should have (which is ironic since Aerojet now owns 
Morton Thiokol) Aerojet had a single piece unit SRB, no joints, ready to 
test. James Fletcher, the head of NASA at the time and a "good friend of 
Utah" was able to get the contract for Thiokol. The only issue was the SRBs 
had to be shipped to Utah for refurbishment and refueling. The SRBs had to 
be segmented to fit on a railcar. 

Another company that got special treatment was Rocketdyne, part of Rockwell 
International. They were a big California company, lots of votes. So they 
got the contract for the Main Engines, even though they did not have clue 
one about LH2/LOX engines. Funny thing is, another company, Pratt and 
Wittney, did have experience with high-pressure engines with these 
propellants. They should have won the contract, but once again "political 
pressure" trumped "engineering standards". Rocketdyne gets the deal and 
wastes years blowing up engines on the test stand, while the first shuttle 
flight slips from '77 to' 78 to '79 and finally' 81.

And, more irony. Pratt and Wittney owns Rocketdyne now. 

So basically the system killed people or caused massive delays and cost 
overruns. ﻿
comments.author: Zoomer30

comments.text:
Aerojet never competed for the SRB contract.  Their primary focus at the 
time was the OMS system on shuttle.  Aerojet had many other projects of 
note during the 70's and 80's.  Also at the time the company was focusing 
on smaller rocket assist projects like the JATO.

comments.author: capt rodgers

comments.text:
Just one additional tidbit Dr Nye. Actually SpaceX factory is in 
Hawtorne-CA, and its testing facility is in McGregor-TX. So before rockets 
go to the pad, they go to the McGregor site, which means CA->TX->CA for a 
Vanderburg AFB launch. But with reuse, eventually the first stage will be 
recovered and stay at the launch site, so long term McGregor (and the 
factory) will have a smaller slice of the whole system.
If you think SpaceX is efficient, wait until they mastered first stage 
reuse. Will reduce their costs by 70-80% !
You carefully avoid attacking the largest problem with NASA (and most govt 
agencies) which is human inefficiencies. The lack of someone at the top 
with a direct financial stake in it drives costs higher regardless of all 
of the spread all over the USA model. I believe that NASA could do things 
at 1/3rd of its costs even with all of the districting of its activities if 
it stopped with the managers that fight each other over their own agendas 
and loose focus on the big picture all the time !﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: Astrogirl1usa

comments.text:
+Astrogirl1usa It's possible that future plans for raptor based rockets 
will change this whole thing, as raptor rockets will be too large to be 
transported by road, so they will need to their assembly and test areas 
need to be connected by barge, but that's wayyy out into the future. I 
would however bet SpaceX will keep McGregor for other activities. Anyhow, 
SpaceX is likely to continue to build and launch merlin based rockets until 
at least 2020, perhaps much longer. Merlin rockets are cheap. The plan is 
for building raptor rockets in TX much closed to shore (probably 
brownsville area) but this is far from set in stone.
comments.author: Marcelo Pacheco

comments.text:
+Astrogirl1usa
 McGregor is at least hiring through 2018 and is listed here 
http://www.spacex.com/about/capabilities... where again are they going to 
move testing and development?  California?  Good luck getting an EIS 
through CA in less than a decade.
comments.author: Bob H

comments.text:
+Astrogirl1usa New Mexico is the project that seems to be dead. And that 
was strictly Grasshopper II testing, which was rendered obsolete with the 
almost landing of the CRS-5 stage and might be fully rendered obsolete if 
the DSCOVR launch stage lands.
Please go to http://forum.nasaspaceflight.com/index.php?board=45.0. Talk to 
the experts. I'm not one, but I'm following them. I'm even an Level 2 
(paid) subscriber where we get the scoop even before it hits the media.
I'm 99% sure you are confusing the Grasshopper program with the core engine 
acceptance and stand testing in McGregor.
comments.author: Marcelo Pacheco

comments.text:
+Marcelo Pacheco 
Sigh...  Okay, one more time.  First, you cannot always go by what is said 
in the Wikipedia.  It is not that reliable.  Elon was talking about the 
FUTURE of the McGregor site.  McGregor is not permanent.  In the near 
future; engine testing will be done in New Mexico and California, but NOT 
McGregor.  Second, the Wikipedia does not include what will happen in the 
future; it only has what is in the present and what is in the past, as 
facts.  I am happy to see you have support and enthusiasm for SpaceX, but 
you are wrong about McGregor being a permanent engine testing facility. 
 Now, I am done, no matter what else you drag up.  Have a nice life.
comments.author: Astrogirl1usa

comments.text:
+Astrogirl1usa http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpaceX_launch_facilities 
topic SpaceX Rocket Development and Test Facility, McGregor, Texas

The company purchased the McGregor, Texas, testing facilities of defunct 
Beal Aerospace

See, no expiring lease. They purchased the land. SpaceX facilities at 
McGregor are not temporary.
comments.author: Marcelo Pacheco

comments.text:
+Marcelo Pacheco
Wrong!  You will see.  McGregor has maybe another year.  I'm done.
comments.author: Astrogirl1usa

comments.text:
90% of SpaceX usage of McGregor is ground activities. That's not going 
away. There is NO talk whatsoever of SpaceX moving stage testing and 
acceptance anywhere else. They build the rockets / dragon in Hawthorne-CA, 
and ship to McGregor for testing and acceptance, then it ships to the 
launch site. That is totally independent of Grasshopper flight tests.
comments.author: Marcelo Pacheco

comments.text:
+Marcelo Pacheco
McGregor was never meant to be permanent.  It will be shut down, I think 
it's suppose to be sometime in 2016. They only went to McGregor for the 
height they were allowed to reach with Grasshopper.  As for engine testing, 
after McGregor shuts down, that will be done in California, but not at 
SpaceX headquarters, of course.  I believe there was talk about doing 
engine tests at the new launch facility, after it's built too.  I believe 
you are right about Grasshopper tests being finished.  I didn't care about 
whether it was, or not when I made the comment.  My point was to say that 
McGregor is going to close.  I do think I read somewhere that the 
Grasshopper tests are finished.  McGregor is only temporary in any case.
comments.author: Astrogirl1usa

comments.text:
+Astrogirl1usa Are you perhaps confusing the Grasshopper program with 
ground testing activities at McGregor ? I closely follow SpaceX @ 
nasaspaceflight and never heard SpaceX will leave McGregor. However the 
Grasshopper program @ McGregor is essentially done, whatever they need to 
test, they can now test during re-entry of F9R first stages, with a few 
tests to be done with recovered and reflown stages.
comments.author: Marcelo Pacheco

comments.text:
The McGregor site was chosen for the height SpaceX was allowed to let their 
test rocket go to.  After the initial testing with Grasshopper is over; 
McGregor operations are slated to be discontinued.  SpaceX has no permanent 
plans for McGregor.  The land is merely being leased by SpaceX and will be 
abandoned soon.  If I remember right, it's supposed to be shut down by 
2016, maybe earlier.
comments.author: Astrogirl1usa

comments.text:
I agree with the fact that NASA should be able to do stuff for 1/3rd the

comments.author: FantasticBob7000

comments.text:
+Akin Khoo Russian engines are more efficient - SpaceX's engines have 
better thrust/weight ratio and are *much* cheaper to build.  You can argue 
technical superiority of the Russian engines, but that wasn't really what 
SpaceX was going for.  They were going for cheap and simple rocket engines 
that are easy to use multiple times and have better cost-efficiency in the 
long run.
comments.author: ApocolypseZombie

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Akin Khoo
The topic of this video is cost efficiency not fuel efficiency.  SpaceX is 
currently more cost efficient than all other launchers.
comments.author: FantasticBob7000

comments.text:
i am quite sure the russian and chinese are higher efficiency than SpaceX. 
hell even the Altas rocket are powered by russian engine, that is just how 
much more superior russian close cycle engines are... SpaceX engine are 
still open cycle, where part of the fuel that drives the pump is discarded 
without burning because they don't have the technology to feed the heated 
gas back into the engine without it blowing up.
comments.author: Akin Khoo
